title: The Distributive Property
kid_friendly_explainer: The Distributive Property: $a(b + c) = ab + ac$ and $a(b - c) = ab - ac$.
It lets you multiply a number or variable across everything inside parentheses.
You can also use it backwards (called factoring) to pull out a common factor.
Pro tip: Draw arrows from the outside number to each term inside. One arrow per term!

core_rules.name: Basic Distributive Property
core_rules.plain_english: Multiply the term outside the parentheses by each term inside the parentheses.
core_rules.latex: a(b + c) = ab + ac \quad \text{and} \quad a(b - c) = ab - ac

core_rules.name: Distributing a Negative
core_rules.plain_english: When distributing a negative sign, multiply -1 by each term inside. This changes all the signs.

core_rules.name: Distributing to Multiple Terms
core_rules.plain_english: The distributive property works with any number of terms inside the parentheses.
core_rules.latex: a(b + c + d) = ab + ac + ad

core_rules.name: Reverse Distribution (Factoring)
core_rules.plain_english: You can factor out a common term from an expression by using the distributive property in reverse.

walkthrough: Multiply 3 by the first term: \(3 \times x = 3x\).
Multiply -2 by the first term: \(-2 \times y = -2y\).
Note: negative times negative gives positive!
Find the greatest common factor (GCF) of 12 and 18: GCF = 6.

teacher_notes: Emphasize that EVERY term inside must be multiplied. Students often forget to distribute to all terms.
Distributing a negative is especially tricky: $-(x + 4) = -x - 4$, not $-x + 4$. Use many examples.
Draw arrows from outside to inside to visualize the distribution. This helps students remember to hit every term.
When combining like terms after distribution, encourage students to group terms by type (all $x$ terms together, all constants together).
For factoring (reverse distribution): find the greatest common factor (GCF) first, then divide each term by it.
With nested parentheses, teach students to work from the innermost layer outward, one level at a time.
